Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Binuclear Chemistry of Heterogenized Molecular Catalysts in Solar CO2 Reduction
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Gonghu Li of the University of New Hampshire is investigating recycling carbon dioxide into chemicals, materials and fuels. However, carbon dioxide is thermodynamically stable, and its conversion often requires high energy. This research project constructs innovative catalytic systems to enable carbon dioxide activation via low-energy pathways, in which two metal centers work together to reduce carbon dioxide into fuels under light irradiation. The low-energy pathways will be investigated using both experimental and theoretical methods. This project will also provide excellent opportunities for educating the current and emerging workforce in energy-related fields to increase the national talent pipeline in clean energy, materials and catalysis science. The broader impacts of this project include the development of efficient and robust catalytic systems for carbon dioxide utilization, which will subsequently reduce dependency on fossil fuels and help to mitigate climate change.

Dr. Li is investigating cooperative interactions of surface metal centers in photocatalytic carbon dioxide reduction. In particular, heterogenized molecular catalysts will be synthesized by grafting coordination complexes of Rhenium, Manganese, Nickel and Cobalt onto mesoporous silicas via covalent linkers. The linkers and porous surfaces will be optimized to achieve proper intermolecular distances and geometry. Advanced spectroscopic techniques and density functional theory calculations will be employed to investigate low-energy, binuclear pathways in carbon dioxide reduction using the heterogenized molecular catalysts. The proposed research focuses on fundamental issues in surface chemistry and carbon dioxide -reduction photocatalysis in confined environments. This CAREER award also supports educational activities, including annual solar energy workshops, to effectively disseminated sustainability concepts to K-12 students and the public. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits from the development of innovative catalytic systems for efficient solar energy conversion and sustainable carbon dioxide utilization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to develop innovative hybrid catalytic systems for recycling carbon dioxide into useful chemicals and fuels using sunlight as the only energy input. The hybrid systems consist of transition metal complexes grafted on solid-state surfaces through rationally designed linkages. One specific goal is to enable synergistic effects between neighboring metal sites which work together to carry out the chemical transformation at low energy pathways. This project also aims to integrate laboratory research with education through STEM workshops and science projects for K-12 students.

 

We have developed a library of linkages that can effectively couple transition metal complexes with different surfaces, including silica and light-harvesting semiconductors. A dipodal catalyst was found to operate in carbon dioxide reduction via the proposed synergistic pathway. This project also resulted in the development of new transition metal complexes and new insights into the activity of single atom catalysts. Our work contributed to the field of solar fuels by identifying key factors (linking strategies and surface characteristics) that dictate activities and stabilities of metal-based catalysts on surfaces. The results obtained through these research activities have been disseminated to the communities of interest through journal publications, student theses, conference presentations, and STEM workshops for K-12 students.

 

Through working on this project, nine graduate and eight undergraduate researchers received interdisciplinary training in catalyst synthesis, spectroscopy and microscopy, surface chemistry, and photocatalysis. They acquired knowledge and skills of using a variety of scientific instruments. They also developed skills including planning and conducting research, analyzing experimental results, and presenting results in front of the general public. As a results, many of the student researchers secured industrial positions in instrumentation and product analysis after graduation. Several students were also inspired to pursue a career in renewable energy and other related scientific fields. In addition, this project provided opportunities for nine high school students to work on science projects in solar cells and photocatalysis for environmental applications. Such experience provided valuable inspiration for them to pursue a career in STEM disciplines. Several of the students went to pursue STEM education in colleges including Harvard, MIT, Boston University, Northeastern University, University of Chicago, and Saint Anselm College.

 

We organized STEM workshops for K-12 science teachers and students at events including the NEACT summer conferences, the Kaleidoscope Enrichment Program at Portsmouth Christian Academy in NH, the STEAM for Girls Club at Clinton Middle School in MA, as well as K-12 Nanotech Teacher Conference, Tech Camp, Project SMART at the PI?s home institution. Through these workshops, concepts of renewable energy, catalysis, and nanoscience were broadly disseminated to the society. Participants of the STEM workshops appreciated a better understanding on the relationship between clean energy and better environment.
